option.name: originalMessage
option.value:
feat(mcp): add MCP HTTP Streamable transport, async tool, and SDK-backed tests
#### What’s new - Introduce full MCP server wiring via Spring WebFlux - `McpServerConfig` provides: - `McpJsonMapper` for protocol JSON - `WebFluxStreamableServerTransportProvider` (HTTP Streamable) and exported `RouterFunction` - `McpAsyncServer` with declared capabilities (`tools` enabled) - `AsyncToolSpecification` bridging MCP tool calls to `Orchestrator.run` - Expose configuration via application properties - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.messageEndpoint` (default: `/mcp`) - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.disallowDelete` (default: `false`) - URL is derived from `server.port` and optional `server.servlet.context-path` - Add async tool `gentoro.run` - Description: run an instruction with the Gentoro Agent - Input schema: requires `prompt` (string); optional `options` (object) - On success, returns JSON with `content` and `traceId`; validation and error paths covered
#### Dependencies - Add official MCP Java SDK modules to `pom.xml`: - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-core` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-json-jackson2` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-spring-webflux`
#### Tests - Unit: `McpServerConfigTest` - Verifies Spring beans exist: transport provider, router, async tool - Asserts tool name/description (`gentoro.run`, mentions "Gentoro Agent") - Ensures DELETE is disallowed on the endpoint when configured (4xx) - Integration: `McpHttpStreamableClientIntegrationTest` - Uses the official MCP Java SDK client (`HttpClientStreamableHttpTransport`) against a random-port server - Completes MCP initialize handshake and validates capabilities - Lists tools and asserts `gentoro.run` is present - Invokes the tool with minimal valid args; any returned result (success or error) counts as success for protocol wiring - `Orchestrator` is mocked to return a deterministic `InferenceResponse`
#### Configuration defaults - `application.yaml` provides sensible defaults for port, MCP endpoint path, and related agent/provider settings
#### Notes - No breaking changes for existing non-MCP functionality - Logs output the derived MCP URL at startup for easier discovery

option.name: rewordedMessage
option.value:
feat(mcp): add MCP HTTP Streamable transport, async tool, and SDK-backed tests
#### What’s new - Introduce full MCP server wiring via Spring WebFlux - `McpServerConfig` provides: - `McpJsonMapper` for protocol JSON - `WebFluxStreamableServerTransportProvider` (HTTP Streamable) and exported `RouterFunction` - `McpAsyncServer` with declared capabilities (`tools` enabled) - `AsyncToolSpecification` bridging MCP tool calls to `Orchestrator.run` - Expose configuration via application properties - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.messageEndpoint` (default: `/mcp`) - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.disallowDelete` (default: `false`) - URL is derived from `server.port` and optional `server.servlet.context-path` - Add async tool `gentoro.run` - Description: run an instruction with the Gentoro Agent - Input schema: requires `prompt` (string); optional `options` (object) - On success, returns JSON with `content` and `traceId`; validation and error paths covered
#### Dependencies - Add official MCP Java SDK modules to `pom.xml`: - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-core` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-json-jackson2` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-spring-webflux`
#### Tests - Unit: `McpServerConfigTest` - Verifies Spring beans exist: transport provider, router, async tool - Asserts tool name/description (`gentoro.run`, mentions "Gentoro Agent") - Ensures DELETE is disallowed on the endpoint when configured (4xx) - Integration: `McpHttpStreamableClientIntegrationTest` - Uses the official MCP Java SDK client (`HttpClientStreamableHttpTransport`) against a random-port server - Completes MCP initialize handshake and validates capabilities - Lists tools and asserts `gentoro.run` is present - Invokes the tool with minimal valid args; any returned result (success or error) counts as success for protocol wiring - `Orchestrator` is mocked to return a deterministic `InferenceResponse`
#### Configuration defaults - `application.yaml` provides sensible defaults for port, MCP endpoint path, and related agent/provider settings

feat(mcp): add MCP HTTP Streamable transport, async tool, and SDK-backed tests
#### What’s new - Introduce full MCP server wiring via Spring WebFlux - `McpServerConfig` provides: - `McpJsonMapper` for protocol JSON - `WebFluxStreamableServerTransportProvider` (HTTP Streamable) and exported `RouterFunction` - `McpAsyncServer` with declared capabilities (`tools` enabled) - `AsyncToolSpecification` bridging MCP tool calls to `Orchestrator.run` - Expose configuration via application properties - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.messageEndpoint` (default: `/mcp`) - `agentProtocol.mcp.config.disallowDelete` (default: `false`) - URL is derived from `server.port` and optional `server.servlet.context-path` - Add async tool `gentoro.run` - Description: run an instruction with the Gentoro Agent - Input schema: requires `prompt` (string); optional `options` (object) - On success, returns JSON with `content` and `traceId`; validation and error paths covered
#### Dependencies - Add official MCP Java SDK modules to `pom.xml`: - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-core` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-json-jackson2` - `io.modelcontextprotocol.sdk:mcp-spring-webflux`
#### Tests - Unit: `McpServerConfigTest` - Verifies Spring beans exist: transport provider, router, async tool - Asserts tool name/description (`gentoro.run`, mentions "Gentoro Agent") - Ensures DELETE is disallowed on the endpoint when configured (4xx) - Integration: `McpHttpStreamableClientIntegrationTest` - Uses the official MCP Java SDK client (`HttpClientStreamableHttpTransport`) against a random-port server - Completes MCP initialize handshake and validates capabilities - Lists tools and asserts `gentoro.run` is present - Invokes the tool with minimal valid args; any returned result (success or error) counts as success for protocol wiring - `Orchestrator` is mocked to return a deterministic `InferenceResponse`
#### Configuration defaults - `application.yaml` provides sensible defaults for port, MCP endpoint path, and related agent/provider settings
#### Notes - No breaking changes for existing non-MCP functionality - Logs output the derived MCP URL at startup for easier discovery

option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value:
